Import Prices Show Pervasive Jump,
 Even When Oil Costs Are Excluded
 
 WASHINGTON -- Import prices surged in March, lifted by not only oil but also the biggest jump in nonpetroleum costs on record, a worrisome sign for inflation.
 
 Overall import prices rose 2.8% last month, after increasing an unrevised 0.2% in February, the Labor Department said Friday. Wall Street expected import prices to climb 2.1% in March.
 
 During the 12 months since March 2007, prices increased 15%. Between March 2006 and March 2007, prices climbed by 2.8%.
 
 Petroleum import prices increased 9.1% last month and fell 1.9% in February; prices soared 60.0% in the 12 months since March 2007. Between March 2006 and March 2007, petroleum import prices climbed by 3.1%.
 
 Excluding petroleum, all other import prices rose 1.1% in March, after increasing 0.7% in February. Prices excluding petroleum increased 5.4% in the 12 months since March 2007, nearly double the 2.8% climb between March 2006 and March 2007.

 With Eurozone inflation running at an all time high, don't look for too much action.
 
 There seems to be a MAJOR break on this between US analysts and European analysts. US analysts are used to our central bank responding to economic weakness because the fed has a dual mandate...control inflation and maximize employment. The ECB does not. They have ONE mandate, and that is price stability. Their ideals are a little different from the US. Basically they have built the mandate of their central bank around the idea that economic stability is more important than ensuring growth and that artificial growth (which is what you get when..say...your central bank dumps interest rates to 1% for no logical reason) in the end does more harm than good. 
 
 There are a couple of other factors in play here as well. First, ECB voting member do not seemed convinced that lowering rates and crashing their own currency will actually help with the problem. It is not just dollar weakness that is causing problems in Europe, it is lack of market. It is pretty clear that the US is in for a prolonged period of financial difficulty. Regardless of exchange rate, US consumers are going to be cutting back on luxury goods, which is most of what comes out of Europe. Look at last months retail sales numbers. The only retailers that had results that were less than dismal were china mart and chinaco. Bankers tend to take a little differnt view from a lot of people. They recognize that if you burn your own currency in order to stay competitive, but then inflation eats all your earnings up, you are in worse shape than if you ahd never made those sales to begin with.
 
 The other thing that is in play here is a long held belief from the ECB that Europe needs to work harder to decouple itself from the US. The US is a failing economy. There is no question of that and everybody in the financial world has known it for a very long time. It is not a question of IF, it is a question of WHEN. 
 
 Even if they believed at the ECB that cutting rates would have a positive effect, it is not clear that they would do so, as keeping things as they are is helping force European businesses develop other markets for their products, which the ECB has in the past claimed was "critical to continued prosperity".
 
 Unless and until inflation in the EU slows down, it is unlikely that we will see a rate cut from the ECB. There is simply no room in their mandate to make illogical rate cuts in the face of record inflation numbers, nor would it be logical for them to do so.
